description: Discrete Random Variables and Expectations Start off with an example, using the most normal element we would use in fundamental probability to explain combinations and outcomes in an event, two die. With this two dice we will have 36 possible outcomes. Let $(a, b)$ denote a possible outcome of rolling the two die, with the number on the top of the first die and b the number on the top of the second die.
title: Random Variable and Expectation_

description: In this section we will show how double and triple integrals can be used to find the mass and center of gravity of inhomogeneous laminas and three-dimensional solids.

description: /* jshint esversion: 6 */function plot() {functionPlot({target: "#root",width: $('#root').width(),height: $('#root').width() / 1.77,yAxis: {domain: [-5, 5]},tip: {renderer: function () {}},grid: true,data: [{fn: "x^2",derivative: {fn: "2 * x",updateOnMouseMove: true}},{fn: "sin(x)",},{fn: "x - 1/6 * x^3",}]});}$(document).ready(function () {plot();});$(window).resize(function () {plot();});
title: Function-Plot
